Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Engineering Biological Robustness through Synthetic Control

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1350498
Moon, Tae Seok

Natural regulatory networks have complex features to ensure robust cellular functions. However, robustness comes with a price: it requires cellular resources, imposing a metabolic burden on cells. The overarching goal of this project is to understand the principles of biological robustness by building genetic circuits from the bottom-up. The work will benefit society by providing design principles and engineering strategies to ensure that biological systems behave as designed over a long time scale. In addition, while the PI's focus is to apply design principles to biochemical production platforms, the same approach can be applied to other problems, such as environmental and health issues, by replacing the actuator modules with toxic chemical degrading pathways and pathogen killing mechanisms.

The overarching goal of this project is to understand the principles of biological robustness by building genetic circuits from the bottom-up. The intellectual merits of this project are threefold. First, it will enable the quantitative assessment of the burden imposed by individual genes, providing guidelines for part selection in synthetic biology. Second, it will help address the issues of metabolic burden and evolution by using genetic circuits. Last, by building functions from the bottom-up, hypotheses regarding the dynamics and evolution of highly interconnected natural regulatory networks will be tested. The research approach will involve (i) the identification and characterization of sensory and gene regulatory elements, (ii) the building of negative feedback loops and redundant circuits, and (iii) the implementation of these synthetic circuits in microbial cell factories for chemical and drug production.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our long-term goal is to understand the principles of biological robustness by building genetic circuits from the bottom-up. In this project, we have built several genetic circuits and obtained key insights into biological robustness.

 

Key outcomes:

 

[1] It is unclear how the protein regulators in a sequestration-based cascade collectively control the output dynamics. A key challenge in quantitatively understanding the regulatory cascade dynamics is that the cascade is intricately integrated within more complex networks. By building and characterizing synthetic circuits in Escherichia coli, we decoupled the Pseudomonas aeruginosa ExsADCE regulatory cascade from the complex endogenous global network. This bottom-up approach allowed us to quantitatively determine the circuit dynamics and to discover important factors that enable robust and rapid gene expression responses. Specifically, we achieved the construction and quantitative analysis of the ExsADCE cascade, to our knowledge, the longest sequestration-based circuit built so far. Our computational and experimental results demonstrated that the seemingly unnecessary complexity in gene regulatory networks allows cells to rapidly and robustly control gene expression dynamics. Understanding the principles that govern the dynamic control of gene expression is necessary for predicting complex system-level behaviors and engineering robust gene expression dynamics for a wide range of biotechnological applications.

 

[2] We have built the complex, sequestration-based, genetic memory circuits in which the bistable range can be precisely predicted and easily controlled over an extensive range of input signals. Our computational and experimental results demonstrated that the complexity in gene regulatory networks allows cells to robustly respond to fluctuating environmental conditions, deepening our understanding of biological robustness by building complex circuits from the bottom-up.

 

[3] We have successfully developed genetic sensors that respond to environmental signals. For example, we have developed small, synthetic, heat-repressible RNA thermosensors for the first time. These thermosensors consist of a recognition site for ribonuclease E, an enzyme that degrades the mRNA at high temperatures (GFP expression OFF at ~37'C), and its complementary sequence that can sequester the site in a stem-loop structure at low temperatures (ON at ~27'C).

 

[4] We have constructed, for the first time, AND and NAND gates that can respond to temperature and pH, two signals that have relevance in real-world applications. We mined and engineered genetic sensors that respond to pH and temperature, and integrated these sensors into complex genetic circuits. These circuits lay the groundwork for the implementation of complex, environmentally-responsive genetic circuits in metabolic engineering, environmental, and medical applications.

 

[5] Though antisense RNA (asRNA) regulators have been used broadly in genetic engineering applications, there remains no consistent set of design rules for predictable asRNA behavior. Several studies have attempted to develop such rules, but they have led to conflicting results. We performed a large-scale analysis of various asRNA design parameters in order to develop generalizable asRNA design rules. Over one hundred unique asRNA regulators were analyzed, and both target gene repression and off-target effects were considered. Three simple design rules were developed, and were subsequently verified by applying these rules to the design of asRNA regulators in a complex genetic circuit. This comprehensive study resolves inconsistencies in the literature and provides a simple guide for future asRNA design.

 

[6] We have employed the type-II CRISPR system from Streptococcus pyogenes and synthetic asRNAs to repress or derepress target genes in a programmable manner. Specifically, we demonstrated that the repressed target output by the CRISPR interference system can be restored by activating transcription of asRNAs that sequester their target single guide RNAs. In addition, we have developed a combined STAR (small transcription activating RNA) and asRNA system for the first time, establishing a methodology for integrating multiple RNA regulators to construct complex circuits.

 

[7] Biological systems have finite cellular resources, and competition for these resources can lead to interference between seemingly independent genetic circuits. Many sophisticated cellular functions require complex genetic circuits, which demand resources and can negatively affect other circuits. Although recent studies have shown the effects of resource competition on circuit behaviors, natural mechanisms that decouple such interference remain unclear. For the first time, we experimentally demonstrated that negative feedback can significantly reduce resource-coupled interference in regulatory circuits.
